author: Hauteclaire Stassin
text:
For the first time I feel I should actually spare a few minutes of my life to write the following, hoping that it can make a difference for even just one person. In short: avoid Vestiaire Collective, at all costs. 

1) VC customer service is appalling. Any problem you have to report becomes at best a time-wasting nightmare, at worst a money-wasting hell. 
— No contact number, only a chat 
— You have to go through an ill-designed automated customer service anyway
— Staff is incompetent. They don't actually read complaints, they just deliver an empty apology and copy-paste a line taken from VC policy: totally unhelpful.
— You’ll be chatting with multiple agents to solve an issue and you’ll have to spend time to catch them up with your issue and its status every time (again, they don’t read) 
— You have to chase them to get updates, they’re really not on top of things
— They lie ALL THE TIME. And when you catch them in the middle of a lie, they continue to lie. This is quite difficult to handle — how do you deal constructively when confronting dishonesty? (Not a rhetorical question, I’m really asking.)

From a seller's POV: 
1) VC take too much from each sale without providing any kind of decent service
2) They spam you to ask for price reduction several times a week (imagine if you have more than one item listed...)
3) Their offer system is not binding. If you accept a lower offer from a potential buyer, they don't actually have to buy. However, people who previously liked your item will get a notification saying this: “Pssst! You didn't hear it from us, but another member has successfully negotiated the price of [Image of item]. The seller is ready to reduce their price to the amount shown below”. From that point on, you will receive only same or lower offers... Very unlikely you’ll sale at original price.
3) There is always an excuse for payment issues/delays: 
— Maybe it's your bank (it never is, believe me), in which case you have to check yourself and get back to them
— Maybe VC didn't register the item as received, even after you got an email saying: "your item was delivered 72 hours ago, and your buyer hasn’t flagged any problems. Your payment will be issued within 5 working days”. 
4) Their authentication process is a joke (more on that later), same for the verification: they constantly find issues on new items and cancel your sale or ask you to revise the price substantially. Imagine you accept to lower your price by £200, only to find out later through the buyer chat that he/she accepted a £100 discount… You read that right: VC will blatantly lie to make more than you think from a sale! 
5) "Direct shipping" offers no protection: if you send an item that gets damaged in transit or by the buyer, VC will cancel the sale and return your broken item without compensation. As a seller, you’ll always be the loser in a transaction.

From a buyer's POV: 
1) Their authentication process is a joke: fakes are accepted all the time. Imagine: you paid the price for a real [whichever brand] + their authentication fees, and you get a fake. You're disappointed, but you can send it back within 72 hours so you don't worry. Then, VC tell you that they stand by their judgement, so they won't accept your return but give you the "opportunity" to relist without extra charge. If you accept, you're selling an item that you know is fake, hoping to fool somebody else… Now, imagine that someone buys your item: you don't feel great about it, you send it anyway, and now VC say it's a fake and cancel the sale. The item is returned and you can't relist it. You've lost money, time, and ended up with an item you don't want in your closet.
2) The verification process is another joke: they will send you a damaged item listed as "new", and when you complain they’ll say that it was perfect when they inspected it. Again, that one will be on you.
3) You find a rare item: you negotiate, you buy, you get a notification of the arrival at VC for authentication, and then it “disappears” in the warehouse. You complain to get a refund (the seller may also get money from the sale but not necessarily: VC lie about receiving items if proof is missing). Meanwhile, someone in VC is most likely wearing or reselling the item you spent time negotiating for yourself… 
4) UK/EU: they overcharged you with taxes even if the amount is below the threshold, and you cannot do anything about it. 

I know this is just another bad review added to the pile of so many others, and it’s obvious that Vestiaire Collective do not care at all about bad reviews — I have no hope for any kind of change on their part. The only plausible option is to stop using their platform and start using others. The price of dishonesty should be self-destruction; so please, let's just all let Vestiaire Collective die.
title: Avoid at all costs

author: Rosie Brennan
text: I bought an item from Vestiaire over a month and a half ago, the seller dropped the item off at the designated drop-off point the day after I paid and it hasn't moved since. The seller has been chasing Vestiaire with no joy from any customer service people, I have been talking to them for over a month also without any resolution at all. They have told me that the parcel is at the drop off point so I know the seller has done her job but it still hasn't moved and each rep that I speak to (a different one each time) keep saying exactly the same thing: they are investigating it, thank me for my patience and that they will be in touch when they can. My patience has totally run out, I'm moving house in 4 weeks time and at this rate I won't live at the property when (if!) it finally does arrive. I have asked them to just refund my item as it is clearly not going to be delivered to me, a few reps have said they will but generally they ignore my request completely and nothing happens. The seller only gets paid on a successful delivery so in theory they have not only taken my money, but also taken the seller's item. Do not use this app, considering this app is for fairly expensive designer items, it's not worth it.
title: Paid for an item that they lost in their system

author: Taoran Zhao
text:

From before they have a customer service line you can at least call to, to now there is basically no customer service at all. all inquiry will respond on their preference (I have gotten whole bunch legit inquiry that never gotten responded). Not even mentioning the high fee they charge, it is frustrated both as seller and buyer, because you cannot sell/buy items at competitive rates. At this point, I am just so exhausted with them and I am leaving VC for good. I feel really bad for all the sellers that are still selling on the site. There are definitely more great site options out there.

author: M Williamson
text:
I’m new to the site and have made two purchases in the last 3 days. Both purchases were cancelled after my payment was taken because the item isn’t available. 1) Why are items listed that aren’t available? Why doesn’t VC require sellers to remove items or charge sellers for cancelling transactions? 2) Why does VC take payment from my card BEFORE ascertaining whether the item is available or not. They take your money and hold it for a few days before issuing a refund. The process is totally backwards - no money should be debited until VC checks that the item is actually available. 

I won’t use the site again.

EDIT: The response from VC below is disingenuous. The transactions were both cancelled because the item wasn’t available (not because the sellers failed to send the item within 7 days). My point still stands - VC should check whether the item is available before debiting a customer’s card.

author: Defeated
text:
Bought a superfake bag from the UK. Item was shipped to France, "authenticated" by "experts" who have no experience at all dealing with superfakes (convincing fakes with logo cards and logo dust bags). They need to have much higher hiring standards in France. The bag was a French brand, and STILL they cannot recognise real from fake. Actually not a bad business model - they don't take any financial responsibility from selling fakes. The buyer gets duped by the seller, and bears all financial costs.

How did I know the bag is a fake? I compared it with professional photos of the same bag taken by a legitimate luxury e-store. The size was wrong. The logo text was wrong. The zipper was also the wrong size. Honestly, who are these people they hire?? They should hire me. I wrote a whole essay for them, with proof. It was checked by two separate people, and still they couldn't do the right thing.

Sell all the things you need to sell, and then GET OUT! It's terrible that their staff earn money from doing such a bad job. Fakes are terrible for the economy, for French fashion. It is simply unforgivable to circulate fakes!

And I won't trust them to "resolve" this issue. I already sent multiple support emails. It was checked by two people. I even warned them NOT to send the seller the money yet, but they didn't listen.
title: Bought a superfake bag from the UK
